name: Armenian Oak
description: A majestic native tree of Armenia, considered a national symbol. It can live for hundreds of years and provides durable wood.

name: Juniper Tree
description: Sacred in Armenian tradition, juniper trees are evergreen and often grow near monasteries. They are used in incense and medicine.

name: Walnut Tree
description: Widespread in Armenia, the walnut tree provides nutritious nuts and strong, dark wood prized in furniture making.

name: Wild Pear Tree
description: Native to the Caucasus region, the wild pear tree bears small, tart fruits and contributes to Armenia’s biodiversity.

name: Silver Poplar
description: A tall, fast-growing tree common along rivers in Armenia. Its white-backed leaves shimmer in the wind, giving it a silver appearance.

name: Hornbeam
description: A hardy deciduous tree found in Armenian forests. Known for its tough wood, used traditionally for tools and construction.

name: Beech Tree
description: Common in northern Armenia, beech trees form dense forests and provide valuable timber.

name: Pine Tree
description: Armenian highlands are home to native pine forests, providing resin, timber, and shelter for wildlife.

name: Apple Tree (Wild)
description: Wild apple trees grow in Tavush, bearing small fruits that are ancestors of cultivated apples.

name: Maple Tree
description: Maples grow in Armenian forests, known for their beautiful leaves and hardwood.

name: Ash Tree
description: Found in Syunik and southern regions, ash trees are valued for their elastic wood used in tools and furniture.

name: Willow Tree
description: Willows thrive along Armenia’s rivers and streams, their flexible branches used traditionally in basket weaving.

name: Chestnut Tree
description: Chestnuts are found in Dilijan’s forests, their nuts used in Armenian cuisine.

name: Cypress Tree
description: Tall and slender, cypress trees are planted near Armenian monasteries for their symbolic meaning.

name: Cherry Tree (Wild)
description: Wild cherries in Tavush provide small, sweet fruits and vibrant spring blossoms.

name: Elm Tree
description: Elms grow in Lori’s river valleys, known for their strong wood and shade.

name: Service Tree
description: A rare tree in Syunik, its fruits are used in traditional medicine and food.

name: Mulberry Tree
description: Widely planted across Armenia, mulberries are famous for making Armenian mulberry vodka (tuti oghi).

name: Rowan Tree
description: Rowans grow in highland forests, their red berries adding color to Armenia’s landscapes.

name: Birch Tree
description: Birches grow in clusters in northern Armenia, easily recognized by their white bark.

name: Fig Tree
description: Figs thrive in warmer parts of Armenia, especially in Ararat valley orchards.

name: Plum Tree
description: Wild plums are common in Tavush, their fruits used in traditional Armenian sauces like tkemali.

name: Hackberry Tree
description: Hackberry trees are found in Khosrov, with sweet edible fruits and strong wood.

name: Linden Tree
description: Known for fragrant blossoms used in tea, linden trees grow in Dilijan forests.

name: Pear Tree (Cultivated)
description: Cultivated pear varieties are widely grown in Syunik and Ararat orchards.
